Posts.Content: LRAllenM12 wrote: I'm about 3 months off my chemotherapy, and although I'm pleased with the hair growth on my head, I've got hair growing in places I didn't have it before -- all over my face.  Mainly on my cheeks from my ears nearly to my nose, there is a dark soft fluff of hair.  I also have some down my neck.  Anyone else experiencing this?  I'm on Tamox, (one month), but those on that board said this SE is more than likely from the chemo. Thanks! Lisa ~ "Courage is being scared to death -- but saddling up anyway" John Wayne. Lisa's Cancer Blog: lisarmoseley.blogspot.com //Bilateral MX Oct 09 with Node dissection and TE. Silicone Implant Exchange 5/25/10. Dx 9/16/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 1/19 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Facial Hair Issues After Completion of TC-H LRAllenM12 LRAllenM12

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2010 05:28AM LRAllenM12 wrote: Vaniga?  What is that and where can I get some?  Did your hair issue eventually go away?  Thanks so much for the reply!
Posts.Title: Facial Hair Issues After Completion of TC-H LRAllenM12 LRAllenM12

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2010 05:42AM LRAllenM12 wrote: I will definitely have mine removed as soon as I'm not using it anymore, but I can see, Clariceak, where you're coming from.  My cousin still has hers from 2 years ago, and my colleague at work (who was initially staged III) left hers in, and she's had it 6 years past her chemo.  Her cancer did advance a bit with mets, so she has used hers lately.  I think if it's not bothering you, then leave it in until you feel really, really comfy with letting it go.  Good thing to think about though.  I had been convinced that I would have mine taken out... and now I'm thinking, hell, maybe I should leave the thing in!  I don't want to have to go through having it put back in!  Something else to worry about ;)
Posts.Title: Power Port is Powerfully Painful! LRAllenM12 elenalb

Posts.Content: LRAllenM12 wrote: I start my chemo next week, but my power port is so dang uncomfortable I'm about ready to have it taken out and just go with the needles every three weeks!  One of the three nobs on it is so close under the skin that it constantly rubs, and it makes it impossible to wear a bra with any sort of strap -- it just rubs. Anyone else have this problem? Lisa ~ "Courage is being scared to death -- but saddling up anyway" John Wayne. Posts.Title: Power Port is Powerfully Painful! LRAllenM12 elenalb

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2010 03:26PM LRAllenM12 wrote: I've noticed that slowly and over time, my port has become more noticeable -- closer to the surface.  I have a power port, therefore I have three knobs that show the nurses the center for infusion, and at first, only one knob showed through the skin unless you pressed on it.  Now, not only do all three show, but the actual edges of the triangular shaped port are beginning to show. Anyone else had this issue? Lisa
Posts.Title: Power Port is Powerfully Painful! LRAllenM12 elenalb

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2010 03:06PM LRAllenM12 wrote: My power port has continued to move closer closer to the top of the skin, which is very strange and looks even stranger.  It hurts, too -- I mean, it's uncomfortable all the time; like it's just going to work it's way out.  And then I realized that the "bruising" was actually the color of the port, which is purple!  That makes me feel better, becuase I was thinking GOOD GRIEF they sure are messing up my port each time they access it!  LOL!  Now you can clearly see the outline of the entire triangular port as well as the three nobby things that define the infusion area.  Anyone know what causes it to come closer to the surface?  WHen I first got it, you could only see it if you pushed on the skin to find the bumps.  Is this a scar tissue issue? The WHOLE port thing freaks me out, and I know this is irrational, but I keep thinking I'm going to fall or scrape it or something and rip it loose from the vein/artery it's attached to and bleed to death internally.  I think maybe I worry too much.  HAHAH! Lisa
Posts.Title: Power Port is Powerfully Painful! LRAllenM12 elenalb

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2010 09:12PM LRAllenM12 wrote: Once again today I was thankful for the port as I received my Herceptin with no pain at all, while the poor 75 year old man next to me got poked over and over until they finally got a line in.  Ugh.  That would be horrible!  I just never thought my port would move outward and cause me any discomfort.  I guess you exchange one kind of pain for another, and I suppose I have to choose my battles.  :)
Posts.Title: Power Port is Powerfully Painful! LRAllenM12 elenalb

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2010 07:35AM LRAllenM12 wrote: Thanks, StillVerticle!  Isn't that the truth.  They tell you you have cancer -- BLAM!  And then they tell you that you need treatment -- BLAM!  All the while, you probably feel NOT SO SICK, and then they "treatment" begins and it's like you are the sickest you have ever been -- and they took the damn cancer out already!  I cannot wait until they find a way to make you well without making you go through HELL.
Posts.Title: Power Port is Powerfully Painful! LRAllenM12 elenalb

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2010 11:04PM LRAllenM12 wrote: PORT DOC: The skin is almost transparent -- well, I mean, you can see that the bumps are a color, purple-ish.  The skin is very, very thin over the bumps, and it hurts to touch it, like if I put any pressure on it at all, it would just tear the skin and come through.  This is what bothers me.  Also, at my last infusion, they took my blood from the port, and when they pulled back on the syringe, there was a sensation of pulling all the way up my neck almost.  It scared me to death.  It was a nauseating feeling! I can also now feel the wire/catheter above the port -- it is right at the service of the skin as well. I have three treatments left, and if it continues to act like this, I'll have to have it taken out as it might just make it's way out all on its own!
